metadata.event_description: Detective puzzle 'Easter Rhyme' by Moe Zilla

story.full_text:
It's a fun day -- Easter Sunday.
Mary loved to greet that one day! In the sunshine, she felt happy
and her bright new shoes looked snappy. For her church she'd proudly dressed.
But before, she'd made a quest, peeking on the park beside,
where those Easter eggs would hide -- Eggs and candies, flowers too.
Things to eat and things that grew! After church (and wooden seats),
in that park she'd hunt for treats! But a mystery, without warning,
lurked outside on Easter morning. And a special Easter game.
Find the guilty bunny's name! After all the eggs were hid, 
Mary wondered what they did? Someone hid them -- then was gone --
leaving presents on the lawn. "Where'd that Easter Bunny go?"
Mary felt she had to know. Past the park, where lilies grew,
there's a stream that trickles through. Past its bridge, across a field
blooming flowers were revealed. Mary spotted luscious hills,
shining bright with daffodils, "Maybe if I'm not a dum-dum
I'll learn where these lilies come from!" But instead, the meadow air
seemed to glow a magic glare. On the grass, below her legs -- 
shone a thousand Easter eggs! And the eggs were just a fraction
of the crazy Easter action. There, to practice hiding habits,
Mary saw a thousand rabbits! "Hey, who's that?" a bunny shouted.
"We've been spotted! We've been outted!" Then one thousand bunnies turned,
curious what Mary learned. "Look at her! She's found the clues."
"And she's wearing pretty shoes." In the flowers, bunnies rose
wiggling each pinkish nose. White fur, brown fur -- some were grey.
They were everywhere today! "See these eggs that we'll be sharing?
Hiding them takes some preparing!" said the smartest bunny rabbit.
He's the boss. His name is Abbot. "Hiding well takes several tries.
So I teach -- I supervise!" "He's just lazy," joked another.
It was Randy -- Abbot's brother. Randy's grey, with silver legs.
He hid only dark grey eggs. He'd make jokes both dark and funny,
like a wise-guy Easter bunny! And when Abbot tried to preach,
Randy found new things to teach. "Randy, it's important we 
hide our treasures carefully." "Lazy -- that's what's wrong with him.
Abbot needs to hit the gym!" Mary laughed, but suddenly
one bright flash whizzed instantly! Breezes brushed across her face.
like a rabbit in a race. "I'm Speedy," the bunny said
(Cloud-white fur and eyes of red). "It takes work to hide those eggs
so I exercise my legs!" Abbot said, "His pride's quite clear.
He's the fastest bunny here!" Randy laid down six bright eggs.
Speedy crouched down on his legs. "Watch him now. Each egg he budges.
He'll roll it with careful nudges." Speedy stared, as though deciding 
where the eggs should all be hiding. Then he yelled, "It' so much fun.
Count me down now. 3, 2, 1" Poof! He vanished! Blurs of white!
Every egg rolled out of sight! There was grass now, nothing more.
Where the eggs had been before. "Presto!" Speedy yelled to Randy.
"Find them, and I'll give you candy!" Randy grumbled, then said, "Speedy,
For your candy, I'll be greedy." In a hole he disappeared.
But TWO Randys re-appeared. "Look," said Randy, "Ain't this handy?
This is my twin brother, Andy!" More bad jokes, and grey fur too!"
"He's like Randy. Now there's two!" Abbot muttered, "What a psyche.
Everything they do alike -- Walking, talking, hiding eggs.
And they both have silver legs!" Twitching whiskers soon detected.
From their hole, the two ejected, Two grey bunnies raced around
helping Speedy's eggs get found. But then Mary had a thought
something big that she'd forgot. "Whoops! It's Sunday. Time for church!"
"Hey! Don't leave us in a lurch!" Bunny friends all gathered round her
Saying they were glad they'd found her. Giving her an Easter cheer, 
Promising they'd meet next year. "Could I have a souvenir
To remember I've been here?" Mary knew she had to ask it 
Eying Randy's Easter basket. "Randy is so good at finding.
Just one egg could be reminding!" Abbot shook his ears and said,
"I give flowers out instead. "All these eggs are spoken for.
Just for Easter. Not one more." Mary left their Easter-land,
With a lily in her hand. Empty pockets (just her keys),
but she still could feel at ease. Sunshine left a gentle spark 
as she strolled back towards the park. Easter morning always pleases.
Once she even felt some breezes. But in church this day would seem,
as though it had been a dream. But the bunnies that she treasured
Knew that they would be remembered. As she reached down towards her leg, 
now her pocket held an egg! Mary didn't trust her eyes
She had found a big surprise. It was blue and yellow too
Just as though its dye was new. She was touched. They didn't ignore her!
Who had left that egg there for her? Play this special Easter game.
Find the guilty bunny's name!

detection.prompt:
System: You are an ingenious and clever detective who will examine all the clues and reason through all the evidence to solve the crime.

User: Here is a detective puzzle. Please read the story carefully before you decide who the culprit is.

She had found a big surprise. It was blue and yellow too
Just as though its dye was new. She was touched. They didn't ignore her!
Who had left that egg there for her? Play this special Easter game.
Find the guilty bunny's name!

Please analyze all the clues and evidence presented in the story and identify who the culprit is. Explain your reasoning step by step, considering:
1. The motives of different characters
2. The opportunities each character had
3. Any physical evidence or alibis
4. The logical deduction from the clues presented

Solve the mystery. Write down your thought process here.

<THOUGHT PROCESS>
<thought process here>
</THOUGHT PROCESS>

Who are the possible suspects? List them here:

<SUSPECTS>
<names(s) for all suspects here, comma separated>
</SUSPECTS>

Who is the culprit?  There is only one. If possible, include first and last names, as well as any aliases. Answer in the form:

<CULPRIT>
<name here>
</CULPRIT>

Now write down your reconstruction of the events of what actually happened.

<EVENT RECONSTRUCTION>
<event reconstruction here>
</EVENT RECONSTRUCTION>

Finally, explain why the other suspects are innocent.

<WHY THE OTHER SUSPECTS ARE INNOCENT>
<explanation here>
</WHY THE OTHER SUSPECTS ARE INNOCENT>
detection.solution:
<THOUGHT PROCESS>
1. List every rabbit that appears in the story  
 • Abbot – the “boss,” gives out flowers, not eggs.  
 • Randy – joker, hides only dark-grey eggs.  
 • Andy – Randy’s identical twin, therefore also associated with dark-grey eggs.  
 • Speedy – white-fur, red-eyed, prides himself on being the fastest; a blur of wind accompanies his movements.

2. Notice the decisive facts about the hidden egg  
 • Colour: blue and yellow (not dark grey).  
 • Manner of delivery: slipped secretly into Mary’s pocket after she had left the meadow.  
 • Mary “felt some breezes” on her walk – the very same wording the narrator earlier used when Speedy first dashed past her (“Breezes brushed across her face like a rabbit in a race”).

3. Check each suspect against the evidence  

 Abbot – publicly told everyone, including Mary, that he hands out only flowers and that “all these eggs are spoken for.”   
  • Motive: None (he wants to keep all eggs for the children).  
  • Opportunity: Could have, but would contradict his own rule.  
  • Colour mismatch? Not specified, but his stated policy rules him out.

 Randy – specifically described as hiding “only dark-grey eggs.”  
  • Colour mismatch with the discovered blue-and-yellow egg; also he had already crawled back into his hole with Andy.

 Andy – same limitations as Randy.

 Speedy – the only rabbit whose trademark is speed; whenever he moves the text mentions wind or breezes.  
  • Opportunity: Easily able to overtake Mary unnoticed on her walk.  
  • Physical clue: the breeze Mary feels just before the egg appears mirrors Speedy’s earlier entrance.  
  • Motive: He thinks egg-hiding is “so much fun” and likes to show off; also he is not under Abbot’s strict “flowers only” rule in the same way Randy is bound to grey eggs.

4. Logical deduction  
 • Only Speedy has the combination of motive (fun, show-off), means (incredible speed), and opportunity (slip the egg during the unnoticed windy flash).  
 • Colour evidence eliminates Randy/Andy, policy evidence eliminates Abbot.  
 ⇒ Therefore, Speedy is the guilty Easter Bunny.
</THOUGHT PROCESS>

<SUSPECTS>
Abbot, Randy, Andy, Speedy
</SUSPECTS>

<CULPRIT>
Speedy (alias “Speedy the Bunny”)
</CULPRIT>

<EVENT RECONSTRUCTION>
After supervising the test-hiding of eggs, Abbot dismisses the rabbits and Mary heads back toward the park and church, lily in hand, pockets empty except for her keys.  
Speedy, delighted by Mary’s friendliness and eager to perform one last flashy trick, decides to give her a secret souvenir despite Abbot’s rule against handing eggs to outsiders.  
Waiting until Mary is alone, Speedy races up behind her, the rush of his passage producing the same breeze Mary felt earlier when he first appeared. In that split second he slips a freshly dyed blue-and-yellow egg into her pocket and dashes away unseen.  
Later, seated in church, Mary discovers the egg and realises someone has left her a gift—though only we, following the clues, can identify that someone as Speedy.

</EVENT RECONSTRUCTION>

<WHY THE OTHER SUSPECTS ARE INNOCENT>
Abbot: Publicly insisted no eggs be taken; his chosen gift is lilies. Nothing suggests he would break his own rule.  
Randy: All of his eggs are dark grey, whereas the found egg is brightly coloured.  
Andy: Indistinguishable from Randy and therefore tied to grey eggs as well; also last seen underground with Randy.  
Only Speedy had brightly coloured eggs, the trademark windy arrival/departure, and the ability to approach Mary without being observed.  
</WHY THE OTHER SUSPECTS ARE INNOCENT>

original_metadata.reveal_text:
"Use deduction," Mary thought.
"on the clues that you've been taught.
Abbot's warning was quite clear
He wouldn't leave an egg in here.
'All these eggs are spoken for.
Just for Easter. Not one more.'
Randy wouldn't do it, either.
Blue or yellow? He'd do neither!
And it wasn't his twin Andy,
since he'd do the same as Randy!
More in common than just legs --
they'd have the same taste in eggs!"
Then a clue came, like a rocket
"There was nothing in my pocket.
But I know how Speedy teases
and I even felt some breezes.
That's the clue -- the breezes rising.
Speedy tried to be surprising!
Rushing on his furry legs
That's how he delivers eggs!"
Memories in her heart would stay
of this special Easter Day.
Someone left a gift quite funny
And she'd figured out which bunny.
